case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 76 of 1956 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Misc. Writ No. 20 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 76 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Misc. Writ No. 20 of 1954.

facts.text: The facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are number in dispute and they lie in a small companypass.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia is the General Secretary of the Socialist Party of India.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia, is the General Secretary of the Socialist Party of India.

facts.text: U.P. Government enhanced the irrigation rates for water supplied from canals to cultivators.

anchor.surface_text: The U. Government enhanced the irrigation rates for water supplied from canals to cultivators.

facts.text: The Socialist Party resolved to start an agitation against the enhancement of irrigation rates.

anchor.surface_text: The party to which the respondent belongs resolved to start an agitation against the said enhancement for the alleged reason that it placed an unbearable burden upon the cultivators.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia visited Farrukhabad and addressed two public meetings where he instigated the audience not to pay enhanced irrigation rates.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the policy of his party, the respondent visited Farrukhabad and addressed two public meetings wherein he made speeches instigating the audience number to pay enhanced irrigation rates to the Government.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia was arrested on July 4, 1954, at 10 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On July 4, 1954, at 10 p.m. he was arrested and produced before the City Magistrate, Farrukhabad, who remanded him for two days.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia was produced before the City Magistrate, Farrukhabad, who remanded him for two days.

anchor.surface_text: On July 4, 1954, at 10 p.m. he was arrested and produced before the City Magistrate, Farrukhabad, who remanded him for two days.

facts.text: Station Officer, Kaimganj, filed a charge-sheet against Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia before Sri P. R. Gupta, Judicial Officer at Farrukhabad.

anchor.surface_text: After investigation, the Station officer, Kaimganj, filed a charge-sheet against the respondent before Sri P. R. Gupta, a Judicial Officer at Farrukliabad.

facts.text: On July 6, 1954, the Magistrate went to the jail to try the case against Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1954, the Magistrate went to the jail to try the case against the respondent, but the latter took objection to the trial being held in the jail premises.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia objected to the trial being held in the jail premises and obtained an adjournment to move the High Court for transfer.

anchor.surface_text: but the latter took objection to the trial being held in the jail premises. When the Magistrate insisted upon proceeding with the trial, the respondent obtained an adjournment on the ground that he would like to move the High Court for transfer of the case from the file of the said Magistrate.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia filed a petition before the Allahabad High Court for a writ of habeas corpus claiming s. 3 of the U. P. Special Powers Act, 1932 was void under the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondent filed a petition before the High Court for a writ of habeas companypus on the ground, among others, that s. 3 of the U. P. Special Powers Act  Act No. XIV of 1932 , 1932,  hereinafter called the Act  was void under the Constitution.

facts.text: The petition came before division bench of Desai and Chaturvedi JJ who delivered differing judgments and referred to Chief Justice for third judge.

anchor.surface_text: In the first instance the petition came up for disposal before a division bench of the High Court at Allahabad companysisting of Desai and Chaturvedi, Elaborate arguments were addressed before them companyering a wide field. The learned Judges delivered differing judgments expressing their views on the main points raised before them.

facts.text: Agarwala J as third judge agreed with Desai J that s.3 of U.P. Special Powers Act 1932 was inconsistent with Art. 19(1)(a) and restrictions not in interests of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was placed before Agarwala, J., as a third Judge, who agreeing with Desai, J., gave the following answers to the questions referred to him Question No.  i . The provision of sections of the U. P. Special Powers Act, 1932, making it penal for a person by spoken words to instigate a class of persons number to pay dues recoverable as arrears of land revenue, was inconsistent with Article 19 1  a  of the Constitution on the 26th January, 1950.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court allowed the petition and directed release of Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia.

anchor.surface_text: In the usual companyrse the matter was placed before the two learned Judges who first heard the case and they, on the basis of the majority view, allowed the petition and directed the respondent to be released

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh preferred appeal to Supreme Court against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The State has preferred the present appeal against the said order of the High Court.

facts.text: U.P. Special Powers Act was passed in 1932 during British rule, originally for one year, made permanent in 1940 under Governor's rule.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset it would number be out of place to numberice briefly the history of the Act. The Act was originally passed in the year 1932 during the British rule. In an attempt to offset the campaign of number-payment of taxes and other forms of agitation resorted to by the Congress Party, originally it was put on the statute book for one year but in 1940 when the State was under the Governors rule , the Act was made permanent.

facts.text: Between April and June 1954, State Government extended U.P. Special Powers Act to 33 districts including Farrukhabad.

anchor.surface_text: Between April and June, 1954, the State Government extended the provisions of the Act to 33 districts including Farrukhabad district.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 21, 1960 by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. January 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO J.-This appeal raises the question of interpretation of the words in the interest of public order in Art. 19 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Learned Advocate General for State did not canvass correctness of High Court view on certain points and assumed it for this case.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate General, appearing for the appellant. stated before us that be did number propose to canvass the companyrectness of the majority view on one of the important points raised in the case, namely, that the effect of the passing of the Act did number ipso facto deprive a citizen of his freedom of speech guaranteed. under Art. 19 1   a  of the Constitution and its validity should be tested by the provisions of Art. 19 2  thereof.

facts.text: Object of State in appeal was to obtain Supreme Court decision on constitutional validity of s.3 of the Act, not to pursue against Dr. Lohia.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate General pointed out that the object of the State in preferring this appeal was to obtain the decision of this Court on the question of companystitutional validity of s. 3 of the Act and number to pursue the matter against Dr. Lohia.

facts.text: Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia was not present and not represented at Supreme Court hearing; S. Bindra assisted the Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was number present at the time the appeal was heard and was number represented by an advocate. As the question raised was an important one, we requested Mr. N. S. Bindra to assist the Court, and he kindly agreed to do so.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.3 of U.P. Special Powers Act 1932 void as infringing Art. 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that s. 3 of the Act is void as infringing Art. 19 1  a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Prosecution of Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia under s.3 is void.

anchor.surface_text: If so, the prosecution of the respondent under that section is void.

holdings.text: Public order is synonymous with public peace, safety and tranquillity.

anchor.surface_text: Public order is therefore something which is demarcated from the others. In that limited sense, particularly in view of, the history of the amendment, it can be pustulated that public order is synonymous with public peace, safety and tranquillity.

precedents.citation: Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras l

anchor.surface_text: judicial scrutiny by this Court in Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras l . There the Government of Madras, in exercise of their powers under s. 9 1-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949, purported to issue an order whereby they imposed a ban upon the entry and circulation of the journal called Cross -.Roads in that State. The petitioner therein companytended that the said order companytravened his fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Law restricting freedom of speech must be directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it and cannot fall within Art. 19(2) if merely in interests of public order including minor breaches
precedents.cited_holding: unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation under clause 2 of article 19

precedents.citation: Brij Bhushan v. The state of Delhi 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Brij Bhushan v. The state of Delhi 1  followed the earlier decision in the companytext of s. 7  1   c  of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949. Fazl Ali, J., in his dissenting judgment gave the expression public order a wider meaning than that given by the majority view.

precedents.case_name: Brij Bhushan v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed Romesh Thappar equating public order with public tranquillity and giving narrow meaning distinguishing from security of State

precedents.citation: Virendra v. The State of Punjab 3

anchor.surface_text: The learned Chief Justice again in Virendra v. The State of Punjab 3  observed, at p. 317, much to the same effect As has been explained by this Court in Ramji Lal Modi v. The State of U.P. 1 , the words in the interests of are words of great amplitude and are much wider than the words for the maintenance of.

precedents.cited_proposition: words in the interests of are of great amplitude and much wider than for the maintenance of public order
precedents.cited_holding: the expression in the interests of makes the ambit of the protection very wide, for a law may number have been designed to directly maintain the public order or to directly protect the general public against any particular evil and yet it may have been enacted in the interests of the public order

anchor.surface_text: A full bench decision of the Federal Court in Rex Basudeva 1  companytains some observations which give companysiderable assistance to companystrue the words. In that case, the appellant was detained in pursuance of the order made by the Government of U.P. under the U.P. Prevention of Black-Marketing  Temporary Powers  Act, 1947.

precedents.cited_proposition: Connection between activity and public order must be real and proximate, not remote or far-fetched
precedents.cited_holding: The companynection companytemplated must, in our view, be real and proximate., number far-fetched or problematical

anchor.surface_text: The Supreme Court of America observed in Cantewell Connecticut 1  thus The offence known as breach of the peace embraces a great variety of companyduct destroying or menacing public order and tranquillity. It includes number only violent acts and words likely to produce violence in others.

precedents.cited_proposition: Breach of peace includes conduct menacing public order; state may prevent incitement to riot or immediate threat to public safety, peace, or order
precedents.cited_holding: When clear and present -danger of riot, disorder, interference with traffic upon the public streets, or other immediate threat to public safety, peace, or order appears, the power of the State to prevent or punish is obvious

anchor.surface_text: In Romesh Thappers case 1  such an. argument has been repelled by this Court. Patanjali Sastri, J., as he then was, statd the legal position thus at p. 603  1  1950  S.C.R. 594, 600, 601 602. Where a law purports to authorise the imposition of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to companyer restrictions both within and without the limits of companystitutionally permissible legislative action affecting such right,it is number possible to uphold it even so far as it may be applied within the companystitutional limits, as it is number severable.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Doctrine of severability does not apply to laws with wide language covering unconstitutional applications
precedents.cited_holding: Where a law purports to authorise the imposition of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to companyer restrictions both within and without the limits of companystitutionally permissible legislative action affecting such right,it is number possible to uphold it even so far as it may be applied within the companystitutional limits, as it is number severable

precedents.citation: Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: In Chintaman Rao v. The State of Madhya Pradesh the same principle is again restated. Mahajan, J., as he then was observed at p. 765 The law even to the extent that it companyld be said to authorize the imposition of restrictions in regard to agricultural labour cannot be held valid because the language employed is wide enough to companyer restrictions both within and without the limits of companystitutionally permissible legislative action affecting the right.

precedents.case_name: Chintaman Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Wide language making possible unconstitutional application renders entire law void, no severability
precedents.cited_holding: So long as the possibility of its being applied for purposes number sanctioned by the Constitution cannot be ruled out, it must be held to be wholly void

precedents.citation: R. M. D. Chamarbaugwalla v. The Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: R. M. D. Chamarbaugwalla v. The Union of India 2 . In that case the companystitutionality of ss. 4 and 5 of the Prize Competitions Act  42 of 1955  was challenged on the ground that prize companypetition as defined in s. 2 d  of the Act included number merely companypetitions that were of a gambling nature but also those in which success depended to a substantial degree on skill.

precedents.case_name: R.M.D. Chamarbaugwalla v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Doctrine of severability applies if provisions separable based on history, object, and wording distinguishing valid from invalid applications
precedents.cited_holding: laid down as many as seven rules of companystruction. On the application of the said rules it was held that the impugned provisions were severable in their application to companypetitions in which success did number depend to any substantial degree on skill

anchor.surface_text: In R. D. Chamarbaugwallas Case 1  the difference between two classes of companypetitions, namely, those that are of gambling nature and those in which success depends on skill, is clear-cut and has long been recognized in legislative practice.

precedents.case_name: R.M.D. Chamarbaugwalla v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Severability possible where clear-cut distinction between valid and invalid applications exists
